details.thesis_title: The role of magnetospheric convection in the formation of multi-scale ionospheric structuring and F-region instabilities

responsibilities: Examined the impact of different types of data (ionosondes, GNSS TEC and radio occultation data) on ionospheric metrics like hmF2, foF2 and TEC in a data assimilation model
Validated ionospheric scintillation date from commercial radio occultation satellites for the NASA CSDA program by comparing to existing ground- and space-based observations to climatology
Developed a CubeSat mission concept to examine mid- to low-latitude ionospheric irregularities
Analyzed plasma wave observations from Arase to develop a space debris detection method
Investigated the cause of prompt penetration electric fields during major geomagnetic storms using the Multiscale Atmosphere-Geospace Environment (MAGE) model
Compared MAGE model results to Jicamarca F-region vertical drifts observations and to previous modeling
Examined long-term changes in the ionosphere-thermosphere system using the whole atmosphere model, WACCM-X and compared the modeling results to observations of Jicamarca F-region vertical drifts
Prepared my PhD research projects for publication
Characterized traveling ionospheric disturbances from detrended GNSS TEC using spectral methods

Analyzed the occurrence of equatorial plasma bubbles during major geomagnetic storms by comparing multiple data sets including Swarm, DMSP, GNSS TEC and the International Space Station Floating Potential Measurement Unit (ISS FPMU)

Studied prompt penetration electric fields during major geomagneric storms and their effect on plasma bubbles using an inner magnetosphere model, RCM and a coupled inner magnetosphere-ionosphere model SAMI3-RCM and compared these modeling results to ion drift observations and magnetometer perturbations
